Designing a tool to visualise and inspect simulations

My role at Simudyne was to design a product that would enable users to view and play through the simulations they build in real time - a tool that would remove the gap between their code and the ability to control and inspect their model.

Simudyne is an SDK for building, testing and deploying ‚Äòagent-based‚Äô models.

Our users were researchers and analysts who want to test the sanity of their theories using cloud computing and novel paradigms such as agent-based modelling without the need of a computer scientist. The use cases range from testing central bank policies to molecular interactions. The challenge was to design a product general enough to visualise any simulation, whilst meeting the specific needs of each.

Conducting research

The first step in this project was to identify the tasks common to all users. Since the product is not a mass consumer product, but rather a niche technology used by researchers in banks and universities, this involved shadowing users to understand how they used the product, and one-to-one user interviews. At the end of this process, the tasks, pains and success criteria of our users were brought together to understand the problem which needed to be solved.

Modellers needed a tool to build and test their simulations.

I held a workshop with our in-house modellers, some of our users, and our developers, to generate ideas and features that would alleviate pains or allow them to achieve what they wanted more easily. These ideas and features were ranked by usefulness and cost, with the best ones later being used to create a new user flow for how a modeller would now use our product.

Reimagining the user journey

The journey of the user begins at the model design stage. The user would then build the model using the Simudyne SDK, and in real-time, test results and variables in a web based inspector. Once the model is completed, it would then be available in a model lake to allow the user to chain it with other models and conduct larger experiments. The user flow was divided into features of the first design iteration, and features that would come at a later stage. An example of a real use case is given to bring the user journey to life.

Generating ideas

Aside from interviewing and shadowing users, I studied some of the models they were building, as the test of a good design would be to cater for all the models they were building.
